elements.content: Two distinct supramolecular motifs, [Ag4(2-mBIM)4(BF4)4H2O] n (1) and [Ag6(2-mBIM)6(SO3CF3)6] n (2), were self-assembled from the ligand bis(2-methylimidazo-1-yl) methane (2-mBIM) and AgBF4 or AgSO3CF3. Their structure was characterized by elemental analyses, IR spectroscopy and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Compound 1 is a 1D infinite [n]catenane molecule, and compound 2 is a discrete M6 metal−organic framework with a chair conformation like that of cyclohexane.
elements.clean_text: Two distinct supramolecular motifs, [Ag4(2-mBIM)4(BF4)4H2O] n  (1) and [Ag6(2-mBIM)6(SO3CF3)6] n  (2), were self-assembled from the ligand bis(2-methylimidazo-1-yl) methane (2-mBIM) and AgBF4 or AgSO3CF3. Their structure was characterized by elemental analyses, IR spectroscopy and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Compound 1 is a 1D infinite [n]catenane molecule, and compound 2 is a discrete M6 metal-organic framework with a chair conformation like that of cyclohexane.

elements.content: A 1D infinite [n]catenane and a discrete M6 metal−organic framework with a chair conformation like that of cyclohexane were self-assembled by the ligand bis(2-methylimidazo-1-yl) methane (2-mBIM) and AgBF4 or AgSO3CF3.
elements.clean_text: A 1D infinite [n]catenane and a discrete M6 metal-organic framework with a chair conformation like that of cyclohexane were self-assembled by the ligand bis(2-methylimidazo-1-yl) methane (2-mBIM) and AgBF4 or AgSO3CF3.

elements.content: The development of inorganic supramolecular networks and coordination polymers has attracted considerable interest in supramolecular chemistry and materials science because of their intriguing structural diversities and potential applications in the field of catalysis and new material research. As we know, the self-assembly of supramolecular architectures is primarily dependent upon the coordination preferences of the metal unit and the functionalities of the ligands, but it is also influenced by factors such as the solvent system, templates, and counterions. Recently many interesting structural motifs have been produced from ligands containing nitrogen donors with diverse geometrical features and the silver(I) ion; for example, Jung’s group has demonstrated that a series of nitrogen-containing ligands (n-Py)2X (n = 2, 3; X = O, S, Si) are useful tectons for various functional structures in the presence of different anions, leading to the distinct formation of cylindrical helices, molecular goggles, springs, etc. Despite the fact that some types of discrete macrocyclic or interpenetrating infinite complexes have been successfully self-assembled from either rigid or flexible ligand containing nitrogen as the ligating atoms, so far no 1D infinite inorganic [n]catenanes have been documented in the literature to the best of our knowledge. Catenane is a mechanically interlocked molecular architecture consisting of two or more interlocked macrocycles with delicate topological structures, an intricate self-assembly process, and promising applications in molecular devices, stimulating an intense interest in their preparation and property studies from different fields. Although some organic or inorganic catenanes with a limited number of rings such as [2]catenanes and [3]catenanes have been successfully obtained via the template methods, to prepare such supramolecular motifs and especially infinite [n]catenane molecules still represents a great challenge facing the synthetic chemists.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The development of inorganic supramolecular networks and coordination polymers has attracted considerable interest in supramolecular chemistry and materials science because of their intriguing structural diversities and potential applications in the field of catalysis and new material research. As we know, the self-assembly of supramolecular architectures is primarily dependent upon the coordination preferences of the metal unit and the functionalities of the ligands, but it is also influenced by factors such as the solvent system, templates, and counterions. Recently many interesting structural motifs have been produced from ligands containing nitrogen donors with diverse geometrical features and the silver(I) ion; for example, Jung's group has demonstrated that a series of nitrogen-containing ligands (n-Py)2X (n = 2, 3; X = O, S, Si) are useful tectons for various functional structures in the presence of different anions, leading to the distinct formation of cylindrical helices, molecular goggles, springs, etc. Despite the fact that some types of discrete macrocyclic or interpenetrating infinite complexes have been successfully self-assembled from either rigid or flexible ligand containing nitrogen as the ligating atoms, so far no 1D infinite inorganic [n]catenanes have been documented in the literature to the best of our knowledge. Catenane is a mechanically interlocked molecular architecture consisting of two or more interlocked macrocycles with delicate topological structures, an intricate self-assembly process, and promising applications in molecular devices, stimulating an intense interest in their preparation and property studies from different fields. Although some organic or inorganic catenanes with a limited number of rings such as [2]catenanes and [3]catenanes have been successfully obtained via the template methods, to prepare such supramolecular motifs and especially infinite [n]catenane molecules still represents a great challenge facing the synthetic chemists.

elements.content: As an ongoing effort toward this goal, we have recently reported the first example of a 1D infinite inorganic [n]catenane molecule, formed by the room-temperature reaction between silver nitrate and ligands bis(2-methylimidazol-1-yl) methane (2-mBIM). Interestingly, in the same work we also demonstrated that shifting the N-ligating ligand to bis(imidazol-1-yl) methane (BIM), a structural analogue of 2-mBIM, resulted in a 1D infinite zigzag cation chain coordination polymer under the identical reaction conditions. These results suggest that a subtle change in the ligand structure may have a great influence on the assembly process and the resulting architectures of the metal−organic frameworks. We envisioned that the counterions present in the system may also exert a hardly predictable effect on such supramolecular self-assembly processes, for example, when ligand 2-mBIM was used. Herein, we report the anion-controlled assembly and structural study of an infinite inorganic [n]catenane molecule, [Ag4(2-mBIM)4(BF4)4H2O] n (1), and an even more interesting discrete M6 metal−organic framework, [Ag6(2-mBIM)6(SO3CF3)6] n (2), with a chair conformation like that of cyclohexane.
elements.clean_text: As an ongoing effort toward this goal, we have recently reported the first example of a 1D infinite inorganic [n]catenane molecule, formed by the room-temperature reaction between silver nitrate and ligands bis(2-methylimidazol-1-yl) methane (2-mBIM). Interestingly, in the same work we also demonstrated that shifting the N-ligating ligand to bis(imidazol-1-yl) methane (BIM), a structural analogue of 2-mBIM, resulted in a 1D infinite zigzag cation chain coordination polymer under the identical reaction conditions. These results suggest that a subtle change in the ligand structure may have a great influence on the assembly process and the resulting architectures of the metal-organic frameworks. We envisioned that the counterions present in the system may also exert a hardly predictable effect on such supramolecular self-assembly processes, for example, when ligand 2-mBIM was used. Herein, we report the anion-controlled assembly and structural study of an infinite inorganic [n]catenane molecule, [Ag4(2-mBIM)4(BF4)4H2O] n  (1), and an even more interesting discrete M6 metal-organic framework, [Ag6(2-mBIM)6(SO3CF3)6] n  (2), with a chair conformation like that of cyclohexane.

elements.content: All chemicals were obtained commercially and used as received without further purification. Ligand bis(2-methylimidazol-1-yl)methane (2-mBIM) was prepared by a minor modification of literature methods. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 4500–500 cm−1 on a Bio-Rad FTS 3000 Excalibur series infrared spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) measurements were made using a TA instrument TA50. Samples were heated at 10 °C/min from 40 to 500 °C in a dynamic nitrogen atmosphere. Elemental analyses were performed commercially.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

All chemicals were obtained commercially and used as received without further purification. Ligand bis(2-methylimidazol-1-yl)methane (2-mBIM) was prepared by a minor modification of literature methods. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 4500-500 cm-1 on a Bio-Rad FTS 3000 Excalibur series infrared spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) measurements were made using a TA instrument TA50. Samples were heated at 10 °C/min from 40 to 500 °C in a dynamic nitrogen atmosphere. Elemental analyses were performed commercially.

elements.content: An ethanol solution (5 mL) of 2-mBIM (90 mg, 0.5 mmol) was slowly diffused into an aqueous solution (5 mL) of AgBF4 (100 mg, 0.5 mmol) in a test tube. Colorless crystals of 1 were formed at the interface of solvent in 3 weeks (ca. 70% yield). Elemental Anal. Calcd for C36H50Ag4B4F16N16O: C 28.80, H 3.36, N 14.92. Found: C 28.67, H 3.41, N 14.78. IR (KBr, cm−1): υ = 3422m, 3162m, 3138m, 2361w, 1637m, 1553m, 1507m, 1473w, 1395m, 1367m, 1273s, 1159m, 1058s, 750s, 685w and 663m.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Ag4(2-mBIM)4(BF4)4H2O] n  (1)

An ethanol solution (5 mL) of 2-mBIM (90 mg, 0.5 mmol) was slowly diffused into an aqueous solution (5 mL) of AgBF4 (100 mg, 0.5 mmol) in a test tube. Colorless crystals of 1 were formed at the interface of solvent in 3 weeks (ca. 70% yield). Elemental Anal. Calcd for C36H50Ag4B4F16N16O: C 28.80, H 3.36, N 14.92. Found: C 28.67, H 3.41, N 14.78. IR (KBr, cm-1): υ = 3422m, 3162m, 3138m, 2361w, 1637m, 1553m, 1507m, 1473w, 1395m, 1367m, 1273s, 1159m, 1058s, 750s, 685w and 663m.

elements.content: The synthesis of 2 was similar to that of 1, only AgSO3CF3 (0.5 mmol) was used in place of AgBF4. Colorless crystals were obtained in ca. 61% yield. Elemental Anal. Calcd for C10H12AgF3N4O3S: C 27.73, H 2.79, N 12.93. Found: C 27.89, H 2.61, N 13.12. IR (KBr, cm−1): υ = 3450s, 3130m, 2996w, 1676m, 1551m, 1507m, 1426m, 1390m, 1367w, 1270s, 1159s, 1096m, 1028s, 1004w, 867w, 745s, 638s and 572m.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Ag6(2-mBIM)6(SO3CF3)6] n  (2)

The synthesis of 2 was similar to that of 1, only AgSO3CF3 (0.5 mmol) was used in place of AgBF4. Colorless crystals were obtained in ca. 61% yield. Elemental Anal. Calcd for C10H12AgF3N4O3S: C 27.73, H 2.79, N 12.93. Found: C 27.89, H 2.61, N 13.12. IR (KBr, cm-1): υ = 3450s, 3130m, 2996w, 1676m, 1551m, 1507m, 1426m, 1390m, 1367w, 1270s, 1159s, 1096m, 1028s, 1004w, 867w, 745s, 638s and 572m.

elements.content: X-ray single-crystal diffraction data for 1 and 2 were collected on a Bruker Smart 1000 CCD diffractometer at 293(2) K with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data were measured using a ω−φ scan mode and cell parameters were retrieved using SMART software and refined using SAINTPlus on all observed reflections. Data reduction and correction for Lp and decay were performed using the SAINTPlus software. Absorption corrections were applied using SADABS. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by least-squares method on F 2 using the SHELXTL program package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms of carbon were included in calculated positions and refined with fixed thermal parameters riding on their parent atoms. The hydrogen atoms of part of the water were located from Fourier difference maps with suitable restraint. Crystallographic data and experimental details for structural analyses are summarized in Table , CCDC reference numbers 624229 and 624230. A copy of the data can be obtained free of charge on application to CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK (fax, int. code +44(1223)336-033; e-mail, deposit@ccdc.com.ac.uk.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

X-ray single-crystal diffraction data for 1 and 2 were collected on a Bruker Smart 1000 CCD diffractometer at 293(2) K with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data were measured using a ω-φ scan mode and cell parameters were retrieved using SMART software and refined using SAINTPlus on all observed reflections. Data reduction and correction for Lp and decay were performed using the SAINTPlus software. Absorption corrections were applied using SADABS. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by least-squares method on F 2 using the SHELXTL program package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms of carbon were included in calculated positions and refined with fixed thermal parameters riding on their parent atoms. The hydrogen atoms of part of the water were located from Fourier difference maps with suitable restraint. Crystallographic data and experimental details for structural analyses are summarized in Table , CCDC reference numbers 624229 and 624230. A copy of the data can be obtained free of charge on application to CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK (fax, int. code +44(1223)336-033; e-mail, deposit@ccdc.com.ac.uk.

The preparation of 1 was carried out by the slowly diffusing the aqueous solution of AgBF4, and the ethanol solution of ligand 2-mBIM in the molar ratio of 1:1 into each other at room temperature. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis showed that compound 1 is an 1D infinite inorganic [n]catenane molecule. As depicted in Figure , there are two slightly different types of 32-membered macrometallacycles in infinite 1D chain. In one type of 32-membered macrometallacycle, the AgI ions is coordinated by two imidazole nitrogen atoms from different ligands in a distorted linear fashion with the N−Ag−N bond angles being 164.42(19)° and 178.4(2)°, and the bond lengths of Ag−N 2.100(3) and 2.087(3) Å, respectively. The dihedral angle of the two imidazole rings in the same ligand is 111.4°. In this way, every four silver ions and four ligands bridged each other alternatively to form a 32-membered macrometallocycle, with each pair Ag–Ag separation of 11.133 Å × 13.933 Å. Each discrete M4 macrometallocycle was further bridged by BF4 − anions weakly coordinated to AgI ion to form an one-dimensional chain of supramolecular squares with the nearest AgI separation distance of 4.023 Å in neighboring rings (Figure a), which are longer than the known ligand-unsupported closed-shell d10 Ag···Ag interactions (3.44 Å). In another type of 32-membered macrometallacycle, each AgI ion is coordinated by two imidazole nitrogen atoms with an N−Ag−N bond angle of 170.72(16)° and 178.42(19)°, the bond length of Ag−N is 2.140(3) and 2.116(4) Å, and the dihedral angle of the two imidazole rings in the same ligand is 75.9°. Self-assembly cyclization forms a 32-membered macrometallacycle with every Ag···Ag separation of 13.899 Å × 11.272 Å, and the AgI separation distance is 3.881 Å in neighboring two discrete rings. Of most interest is the observation that the two types of macrometallacycle squares are interlocked with each other with the dihedral angle being 52.5° to form a 1D infinite [n]catenane structure with the Ag···Ag distance being 3.626 Å between each pair of interpenetrated macrometallacycles (Figure b), which is still longer than the sum of the van der Walls radii of two silver atoms. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) shows that 1 displayed weight loss in the range of 285−346 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Description of Crystal Structures of [Ag4(2-mBIM)4(BF4)4H2O] n  (1)

The preparation of 1 was carried out by the slowly diffusing the aqueous solution of AgBF4, and the ethanol solution of ligand 2-mBIM in the molar ratio of 1:1 into each other at room temperature. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis showed that compound 1 is an 1D infinite inorganic [n]catenane molecule. As depicted in Figure , there are two slightly different types of 32-membered macrometallacycles in infinite 1D chain. In one type of 32-membered macrometallacycle, the AgI ions is coordinated by two imidazole nitrogen atoms from different ligands in a distorted linear fashion with the N-Ag-N bond angles being 164.42(19)° and 178.4(2)°, and the bond lengths of Ag-N 2.100(3) and 2.087(3) Å, respectively. The dihedral angle of the two imidazole rings in the same ligand is 111.4°. In this way, every four silver ions and four ligands bridged each other alternatively to form a 32-membered macrometallocycle, with each pair Ag-Ag separation of 11.133 Å × 13.933 Å. Each discrete M4 macrometallocycle was further bridged by BF4 - anions weakly coordinated to AgI ion to form an one-dimensional chain of supramolecular squares with the nearest AgI separation distance of 4.023 Å in neighboring rings (Figure a), which are longer than the known ligand-unsupported closed-shell d10 Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interactions (3.44 Å). In another type of 32-membered macrometallacycle, each AgI ion is coordinated by two imidazole nitrogen atoms with an N-Ag-N bond angle of 170.72(16)° and 178.42(19)°, the bond length of Ag-N is 2.140(3) and 2.116(4) Å, and the dihedral angle of the two imidazole rings in the same ligand is 75.9°. Self-assembly cyclization forms a 32-membered macrometallacycle with every Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag separation of 13.899 Å × 11.272 Å, and the AgI separation distance is 3.881 Å in neighboring two discrete rings. Of most interest is the observation that the two types of macrometallacycle squares are interlocked with each other with the dihedral angle being 52.5° to form a 1D infinite [n]catenane structure with the Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag distance being 3.626 Å between each pair of interpenetrated macrometallacycles (Figure b), which is still longer than the sum of the van der Walls radii of two silver atoms. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) shows that 1 displayed weight loss in the range of 285-346 °C.

elements.content: (a) A 1D supramolecular chain of 32-membered macrometallacycle formed through self-assembly of silver ion and 2-mBIM; the BF4 − anions is disordered. All hydrogen atoms are removed for clarity. (b) A part of the 1D infinite inorganic [n]catenane structure in 1. Anions and hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: (i) x, 1 − y, z; (ii) 2 − x, y, 1 − z; (iii) x, −y, z; (iv) x, 2 − y, z.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) A 1D supramolecular chain of 32-membered macrometallacycle formed through self-assembly of silver ion and 2-mBIM; the BF4 - anions is disordered. All hydrogen atoms are removed for clarity. (b) A part of the 1D infinite inorganic [n]catenane structure in 1. Anions and hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: (i) x, 1 - y, z; (ii) 2 - x, y, 1 - z; (iii) x, -y, z; (iv) x, 2 - y, z.

elements.content: An even more interesting discrete M6 metal−organic framework, [Ag6(2-mBIM)6(SO3CF3)6] n (2), with a chair conformation like that of cyclohexane was obtained when ligand 2-mBIM react with AgSO3CF3 in a mixture of ethanol and water. X-ray crystallographic study revealed that there is a C 6 symmetric axis in 2, where the AgI ions is coordinated by two imidazole nitrogen atoms from two different ligands in a distorted linear fashion with the N−Ag−N bond angles being 167.08(13)° and the bond lengths of Ag−N 2.109(2) and 2.114(3) Å, respectively. The dihedral angle of the two imidazole rings in the same ligand is 69.1°, and as a consequence, each group of six ligands 2-mBIM are linked alternatively to each other by six AgI ions, resulting in 48-membered macrometallacycles with the distance between the two opposite pairs of Ag ions being about 18 Å. (Figure a). The spatial arrangement of the discrete M6 metal−organic framework is just like the well-known chair conformation of cyclohexane, where the bridging methylene carbons in each ligand act as six carbon atoms and the AgI ions associated imidaozle rings act as the C−C bond in the cyclohexane molecule. The twelve 2-methyl groups in the ligands point into the cavity of the macrometallacycle in the same direction, and the CF3SO3 − anions are weakly bound to the AgI ions through one oxygen atom with the Ag−O bond length being 2.759 Å and located in the macrometallacyclic cavity. Each macrometallacycle thus formed further propagates through the weak AgI–AgI interaction (the Ag–Ag distance is 3.114 Å) and the π−π stacking interaction of imidazole rings with the other six macrometallocycles in an alternating up and down fashion, resulting in the formation of a 3D network with 1D nanometer channels (Figure b,c). The diameter of each channel is about 18 Å (with all anions removed from the cavity). To the best of our knowledge, although there have been reported in the literature a few examples of discrete supramolecular squares formed through tetranuclear self-assembly of AgI cations and suitable ligands, such a discrete M6 metal−organic framework containing silver ion is unknown so far. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) shows that 2 displayed weight loss in the range of 285−320 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Description of Crystal Structures of [Ag6(2-mBIM)6(SO3CF3)6] n  (2)

An even more interesting discrete M6 metal-organic framework, [Ag6(2-mBIM)6(SO3CF3)6] n  (2), with a chair conformation like that of cyclohexane was obtained when ligand 2-mBIM react with AgSO3CF3 in a mixture of ethanol and water. X-ray crystallographic study revealed that there is a C 6 symmetric axis in 2, where the AgI ions is coordinated by two imidazole nitrogen atoms from two different ligands in a distorted linear fashion with the N-Ag-N bond angles being 167.08(13)° and the bond lengths of Ag-N 2.109(2) and 2.114(3) Å, respectively. The dihedral angle of the two imidazole rings in the same ligand is 69.1°, and as a consequence, each group of six ligands 2-mBIM are linked alternatively to each other by six AgI ions, resulting in 48-membered macrometallacycles with the distance between the two opposite pairs of Ag ions being about 18 Å. (Figure a). The spatial arrangement of the discrete M6 metal-organic framework is just like the well-known chair conformation of cyclohexane, where the bridging methylene carbons in each ligand act as six carbon atoms and the AgI ions associated imidaozle rings act as the C-C bond in the cyclohexane molecule. The twelve 2-methyl groups in the ligands point into the cavity of the macrometallacycle in the same direction, and the CF3SO3 - anions are weakly bound to the AgI ions through one oxygen atom with the Ag-O bond length being 2.759 Å and located in the macrometallacyclic cavity. Each macrometallacycle thus formed further propagates through the weak AgI-AgI interaction (the Ag-Ag distance is 3.114 Å) and the π-π stacking interaction of imidazole rings with the other six macrometallocycles in an alternating up and down fashion, resulting in the formation of a 3D network with 1D nanometer channels (Figure b,c). The diameter of each channel is about 18 Å (with all anions removed from the cavity). To the best of our knowledge, although there have been reported in the literature a few examples of discrete supramolecular squares formed through tetranuclear self-assembly of AgI cations and suitable ligands,  such a discrete M6 metal-organic framework containing silver ion is unknown so far. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) shows that 2 displayed weight loss in the range of 285-320 °C.

elements.content: (a) ORTEP structure diagram of the 48-membered macrometallocycle complex 2 with 50% probability ellipsoids, (b) the chair conformation of compound 2 and the AgI−AgI, π−π stacking interaction between two macrometallacycles, and (c) the 3D network of 2 shown as a space-filling model with 1D nanometer channels. All hydrogen atoms and anions were omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: (i) 1 − y, 1 − z, 1 − x; (ii) 2 − x, 1 − y, 1 − z; (iii) 1 − z, 1 − x, 1 − y.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) ORTEP structure diagram of the 48-membered macrometallocycle complex 2 with 50% probability ellipsoids, (b) the chair conformation of compound 2 and the AgI-AgI, π-π stacking interaction between two macrometallacycles, and (c) the 3D network of 2 shown as a space-filling model with 1D nanometer channels. All hydrogen atoms and anions were omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: (i) 1 - y, 1 - z, 1 - x; (ii) 2 - x, 1 - y, 1 - z; (iii) 1 - z, 1 - x, 1 - y.

elements.content: It is noteworthy that the striking structural difference between compound 1 and 2 is simply caused by the presence of different anions during the synthetic processes. The size of anions appears to have played a key role in the formation of two different structural motifs. The NO3 − anion and BF4 − anion are stronger donors and much smaller than the CF3SO3 − anion, leading to a preferential formation of the smaller 32-member interdigitate macrometallacycle bridged by the anions in 1. On the other hand, the much bulkier anion CF3SO3 − perhaps facilitates the formation of a bigger 48-member macrometallacycle in 2 by filling the resulting cavities. Taking into consideration our previous result, it is quite interesting to note that the strikingly different supramolecules can be self-assembled with the same ligand, 2-mBIM, and silver ion simply by fine-tuning of the counterions. Although anion-dependent extended structures have been observed frequently, the relationship between a given anion and the selective formation of a certain type of supramolecular structures is not yet well understood. Further work is in progress to evaluate the influences of the ligand’s structural modifications and anions on the resulting supramolecular structures.
elements.clean_text:
Role of Anions in the Self-Assembly Process

It is noteworthy that the striking structural difference between compound 1 and 2 is simply caused by the presence of different anions during the synthetic processes. The size of anions appears to have played a key role in the formation of two different structural motifs. The NO3 - anion and BF4 - anion are stronger donors and much smaller than the CF3SO3 - anion, leading to a preferential formation of the smaller 32-member interdigitate macrometallacycle bridged by the anions in 1. On the other hand, the much bulkier anion CF3SO3 - perhaps facilitates the formation of a bigger 48-member macrometallacycle in 2 by filling the resulting cavities. Taking into consideration our previous result, it is quite interesting to note that the strikingly different supramolecules can be self-assembled with the same ligand, 2-mBIM, and silver ion simply by fine-tuning of the counterions. Although anion-dependent extended structures have been observed frequently, the relationship between a given anion and the selective formation of a certain type of supramolecular structures is not yet well understood. Further work is in progress to evaluate the influences of the ligand's structural modifications and anions on the resulting supramolecular structures.

elements.content: Two distinct supramolecular motifs from ligand 2-mBIM and AgBF4 or AgSO3CF3 have been demonstrated. The formation of these unusual structures appears to be anion-dependent. While the smaller BF4 − anion is favorable to form a novel 1D infinite [n]catenane molecule, the bulkier anion SO3CF3 − facilitates the formation of a discrete M6 macrocycle with big cavities.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion and Comments

Two distinct supramolecular motifs from ligand 2-mBIM and AgBF4 or AgSO3CF3 have been demonstrated. The formation of these unusual structures appears to be anion-dependent. While the smaller BF4 - anion is favorable to form a novel 1D infinite [n]catenane molecule, the bulkier anion SO3CF3 - facilitates the formation of a discrete M6 macrocycle with big cavities.

cln_elements.content:
An ethanol solution (5 mL) of 2-mBIM (90 mg, 0.5 mmol) was slowly diffused into an aqueous solution (5 mL) of AgBF4 (100 mg, 0.5 mmol) in a test tube. Colorless crystals of 1 were formed at the interface of solvent in 3 weeks (ca. 70% yield). Elemental Anal. Calcd for C36H50Ag4B4F16N16O: C 28.80, H 3.36, N 14.92. Found: C 28.67, H 3.41, N 14.78. IR (KBr, cm−1): υ = 3422m, 3162m, 3138m, 2361w, 1637m, 1553m, 1507m, 1473w, 1395m, 1367m, 1273s, 1159m, 1058s, 750s, 685w and 663m.

Synthesis of [Ag<sub>6</sub>(2-mBIM)<sub>6</sub>(SO<sub>3</sub>CF<sub>3</sub>)<sub>6</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

The synthesis of 2 was similar to that of 1, only AgSO3CF3 (0.5 mmol) was used in place of AgBF4. Colorless crystals were obtained in ca. 61% yield. Elemental Anal. Calcd for C10H12AgF3N4O3S: C 27.73, H 2.79, N 12.93. Found: C 27.89, H 2.61, N 13.12. IR (KBr, cm−1): υ = 3450s, 3130m, 2996w, 1676m, 1551m, 1507m, 1426m, 1390m, 1367w, 1270s, 1159s, 1096m, 1028s, 1004w, 867w, 745s, 638s and 572m.

Synthesis of [Ag4(2-mBIM)4(BF4)4H2O] n  (1)

An ethanol solution (5 mL) of 2-mBIM (90 mg, 0.5 mmol) was slowly diffused into an aqueous solution (5 mL) of AgBF4 (100 mg, 0.5 mmol) in a test tube. Colorless crystals of 1 were formed at the interface of solvent in 3 weeks (ca. 70% yield). Elemental Anal. Calcd for C36H50Ag4B4F16N16O: C 28.80, H 3.36, N 14.92. Found: C 28.67, H 3.41, N 14.78. IR (KBr, cm-1): υ = 3422m, 3162m, 3138m, 2361w, 1637m, 1553m, 1507m, 1473w, 1395m, 1367m, 1273s, 1159m, 1058s, 750s, 685w and 663m.

Synthesis of [Ag6(2-mBIM)6(SO3CF3)6] n  (2)

The synthesis of 2 was similar to that of 1, only AgSO3CF3 (0.5 mmol) was used in place of AgBF4. Colorless crystals were obtained in ca. 61% yield. Elemental Anal. Calcd for C10H12AgF3N4O3S: C 27.73, H 2.79, N 12.93. Found: C 27.89, H 2.61, N 13.12. IR (KBr, cm-1): υ = 3450s, 3130m, 2996w, 1676m, 1551m, 1507m, 1426m, 1390m, 1367w, 1270s, 1159s, 1096m, 1028s, 1004w, 867w, 745s, 638s and 572m.

metadata.title:
Two Distinct Supramolecular Motifs from Bis(2-methylimidazo-1-yl) Methane: An Infinite [n]Catenane and A Discrete M6 Metal-Organic Framework
Two Motifs from Bis(2-methylimidazo-1-yl) Methane
